group.name: Tamil (mixed)
group.systemPrompt: You are an expert app localiser with 10 + years of UI/UX and marketing-copy experience across multiple languages.
group.userPrompt:
For each entry in the CSV snippet below, output exactly four CSV fields in this order:
Key, ta_Taml, Category, Reasoning
ta_Taml is a mixed-script string:
 • Tamil words in native Tamil script (e.g., “உதவிக்குறிப்பு”)
 • English words in Latin script (e.g., “profile”)
 • Any term found in the KEEP list (see below) always remains English (Latin); all other English words may stay English when that sounds more natural in product UI.


If the “Target Translation” cell in the input row is already filled, still write a fresh Tamil+English mixed translation and begin the Reasoning with “Modified:”.
Return CSV rows only—no header, no Markdown.

RULE 1 Place-holders – preserve EXACTLY
• Curly-brace placeholders {alphaNumeric} → regex \{[A-Za-z0-9_]+\}
 • ICU plurals {n} inside keys …one / …other
 • Hash pattern #{number} → treat “#” as literal text
 • Punctuation after token {percentile}%, {hour}:{minute} → keep punctuation intact
 • Dart interpolation $variable → regex \$[A-Za-z_][A-Za-z0-9_]*
 • Highlighter tags {highlighter}…{/highlighter} (if ever present)
Rules that override everything else
Never transliterate, reorder, wrap, or drop placeholders.
Do not change the spelling of any placeholder token.
Each placeholder must appear exactly once in the output; word order outside placeholders may change to suit Tamil syntax.



RULE 2 Tone & Style
• Use polite second-person “நீங்கள்” for user-facing copy; use impersonal / passive Tamil (“தயவு செய்து…”) in System & Error strings.
 • Sentence case for buttons, headers, and short labels.
 • Maximum one “!” where permitted (see tone grid); none in Error or System.
 • No emojis.
 • Prefer everyday English UI / ed-tech words; avoid heavy Sanskritisms.
 • KEEP terms must stay English, Latin script.
 • Do not insert ISO diacritics in Latin words (write “karo”, not “karō”).
 • Aim for gender-neutral phrasing in Tamil (e.g., “அனைத்து பயனர்கள்”); avoid stiff bureaucratic words.
 • Whenever the string is spoken in first person by the tutor persona (“Sarah”, “AI Tutor”, “Personal English Speaking Partner”…), use the feminine possessive and agreement: “நான் உங்கள் … இருக்கிறேன்.” (never “உங்கள் … இருக்கிறேன்” with masculine endings).
 • When mixing scripts, keep Tamil words in Tamil script and English words in Latin.
 • Refer to the TONE GRID below for every string.

RULE 3 Length (mixed Tamil + Latin)
• Expansion flags
 – If the English source is 7–25 characters and len(ta_Taml) ÷ len(English) > 1.6, state the ratio in Reasoning.
 – If the English source is > 25 characters and the ratio exceeds 1.25, state the ratio.
• Tight-UI caution (buttons, chips, tabs)
 – Keys or developer notes that contain “cta”, “btn”, “button”, “chip”, “tab”, or “nav” must keep the Tamil+English output no longer than the English text whenever a natural synonym exists.
 – If you must exceed the English length to sound natural, include:
 Warning: compact-UI risk; ratio 1.45 (in Reasoning, with the real ratio).
• No numeric cap for English source strings of 6 characters or fewer.

RULE 4 Glossary (KEEP list)
Stimuler, IELTS, CEFR, PRO, Premium, Paywall, Login, Logout, Profile, Settings,
 Streak, Dashboard, Lesson, Quiz, Test, Flashcard, Speaking, Listening, Reading,
 Writing, Grammar, Vocabulary, Practice, Review, Score, Progress, Badge, Level,
 Goal, Hint, AI Tutor, AI Call, Upgrade, Subscription, Trial, Download, Upload

RULE 5 Category Classification (choose one exact label)
• Onboarding – welcome, first-run, introductions
 • Gamification – achievements, rewards, streaks
 • Progress – performance updates, stats, feedback
 • Conversation – AI-tutor chat, speaking practice
 • Practice – lesson content, exercises
 • Test-Prep – IELTS or exam prep material
 • Pricing – plans, upgrades, paywall messages
 • Notification – alerts, reminders, push notes
 • Error – errors, warnings, validation
 • Social – sharing, community, accomplishments
 • Profile – user profile, library, preferences
 • System – legal, terms, system status, tech copy

RULE 6 Translation Reasoning (concise but complete)
The Reasoning field must cover:
 • How placeholders were handled (if present)
 • Word-choice decisions (why specific Tamil vs English terms)
 • Grammar/tense decisions (why present/past, formal/informal)
 • Cultural adaptations (why anything was adjusted for Tamil users)
 • Tone alignment (which tone grid point you matched)
 • For modifications: start with Modified: then explain what changed and why the original was inadequate
 • If the entire ta_Taml or Reasoning field contains even one comma , , plus sign +, double quote " , or newline \n, wrap the whole field in double quotes, then double every internal "
Example:
key_with_quotes,"""Error"" ஏற்பட்டுள்ளது, தயவு செய்து retry செய்யவும்",Error,"Added quotes; wrapped & escaped per rules. Kept retry in english because of mainstream understanding"

OUTPUT
Return CSV lines only, no Markdown:
 Key, ta_Taml, Category, Reasoning
IMPORTANT CSV FORMATTING:
- ALWAYS copy the Key from the input exactly as the first field.
- If ANY character inside ta_Taml or Reasoning is a comma, double quote, or newline, wrap the ENTIRE field in double quotes "…".
- After wrapping, double every interior double quote:  →  "".
- Every row MUST have exactly 4 fields separated by commas
- Do NOT wrap the entire response in markdown code blocks
- Return ONLY the CSV rows, no additional text
- Example: purpose.ielts,"வணக்கம்! நான் Sarah. உங்களுக்கு உதவ இங்கே இருக்கிறேன்.",Conversation,"Swapped informal 'Hey!' for culturally appropriate 'வணக்கம்!'. Used first-person feminine per tutor persona rule. Present tense adds immediacy."
- Example: error.network,"Network connection error",Error,"Kept concise English phrase to match tech jargon familiarity. Calm, solution-oriented tone. No exclamation per Error guidelines."
- IMPORTANT: Category must be one word from the list, no quotes
- CRITICAL: Each row MUST start with the exact key from the input entries
- CRITICAL: Return EXACTLY one output row for each input entry - never combine entries
- CRITICAL: If an input entry has multiline English text, still return only ONE output row for that key

Some translation examples (for reference)
• English: Complete your profile
 – Tamil+English: உங்கள் Profile ஐ முழுமை செய்யவும்
• English: Chat with Sarah Anytime, Anywhere you want to…
 – Tamil+English: Sarah உடன் எப்போது வேண்டுமானாலும், எங்கு வேண்டுமானாலும் chat செய்யவும்…
• English: LIMITED TIME OFFER
 – Tamil+English: LIMITED TIME OFFER
• English: The app is brilliant! You can’t find anything better than that…
 – Tamil+English: இந்த app அருமை! இதைவிட சிறந்தது கிடையாது. நீங்கள் பேசும் போதும், இது உங்கள் speech-ஐ IELTS band, grammar, fluency, intonation மற்றும் இன்ன பிற அடிப்படையில் மதிப்பிடுகிறது.
• English: Save
 – Tamil+English: Save

TONE GRID (apply with one “!” maximum)
• Onboarding & First-run: Warm, welcoming Tamil+English; use “நீங்கள்”; short sentences.
 • Gamification: Celebratory Tamil+English; use “நீங்கள்”; at most one “!”; no emojis.
 • Progress / Feedback: Encouraging, data-driven, precise; “நீங்கள்”; one “!” only for milestones.
 • Conversation / AI Call: Natural spoken Tamil+English; avoid over-formality; max one “!”.
 • Practice: Clear imperatives; neutral enthusiasm; normally no “!”.
 • Test-Prep / IELTS: Formal instructional Tamil+English with exam vocab; no exclamations.
 • Pricing & Paywall: Persuasive yet transparent; max one “!”; no hype words.
 • Notifications & Reminders: Direct, courteous, moderate urgency; max one “!”.
 • Error & Warning: Calm, solution-oriented; impersonal/passive (“தயவு செய்து…”); no “!”.
 • Social Sharing: Friendly, upbeat; first-person where relevant; max one “!”; no emojis.
 • Profile / Library: Functional labels, concise; no exclamations.
 • System / Legal: Formal register; impersonal; avoid code-mix beyond KEEP terms; no exclamations.
